title: hmmm...
content:
Well, I took the typing course in high school in 9th grade. As I recall, they start you off doing nothing but "Home Row," which is the resting position for your hands... ASDF JKL;
We had a sheet with rows of 'words' to type--some real, some not. Stuff like FJFJFJFJF DAD K:K DAD K:K SFS JLJ and so on. Just practice for your coordination.
From there, we introduced fingers' upper and lower neighbors one at a time. E and I, C and N, and so on. I think the last letters we learned were the "reach for the middle" guys like T, Y, B, and N.
Really, I'd say if you were determined to learn to type, look for a booklet/packet that sets a progression up for you, and work through it one page per day.
The alternative would be to find a chart that shows you which fingers to use for which keys, and take the time to drill yourself with it--even if your typing is mind-bogglingly slow, force yourself to adhere to the keys. It'll pay off in a week when you're able to type 30-40 wpm... and later, when you're blazing away at over 70.

My crowning achievement in the typing class was doing 72wpm, using the backspace key over 100 times in the 60 second test. BAM.

title: Re: hmmm...
content:
That sounds pretty similar to the way they taught us in high school too. My crowning achievement was 127wpm, thanks to the predictable nature of the words and the fact that you could start typing about two seconds before the screen was drawn - by the time the program was ready to start accepting input you could already be about five characters from the end of the line [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-dexter.gif[/img]

Although I already knew how to type then (although not "properly") I did notice a real improvement in my made up typing style after doing those progressions, so it really does help!
